Derek James wrote:

>On 10/31/05, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>>  Why not just recieve the board state and return a
>>>suggested move?
>>>      
>>>
>>        I guess the problem with this is what language would you be
>>using then they tried to pass you the data.
>>    
>>
>
>I think the format in which they're passing data to a player program
>is fine.  The current board state is just an input vector 64 entries
>long, and each space is either 1/0/-1 for friendly/unoccupied/enemy,
>which is fine.  What I'm quibbling with is that they want each program
>to evaluate all possible board states 1ply deep.
>
>Why not just pass the board state to the player each time step and
>return a suggested move (e.g., a 64-long input vector with zeros for
>non-moves and a 1 for the suggested move?
>  
>
I suppose the reason is that this is a tradition within machine learning 
circles - whereby you throw a load of board states at an eval function 
and pick the one that rates as being the strongest position. I agree 
that ideally the competition eval scheme would take a board state and 
suggest a move. It would then be up to the entrants to decide how they 
wish to generate a move, the above scheme being just one possibility.

On the other hand if you open up the competition too much then it 
becomes much harder to oversee and ensure that no-one is cheating, e.g. 
if submissions are made in some obscure language you are unfamiliar 
with. Also the limited formats make analysis of the functionality easier.

Ian said:

>Given the difficulty we are having with TTT, I 
>thought Othello was a little out of our league for the moment.
>
Yeh. Although I don't think we, or at least I, have tried this 1-ply 
look-ahead approach. All my experiments to date have had 9 outputs, one 
for each possible response. Your eval function did evaluate all possible 
board states, so it's like 1-ply look-ahead, but how many outputs are 
you using?

BTW I'm working towards a new code release and right now I'm working on 
feed-forward only networks just in case I decide to have a go. Hopefully 
it will be easy enough to generate an s-expression from a network in 
order to create a submission for the online leagues.

Colin.
